page.title: 15Meon Hill Mickleton
page.content: Meon Hill,637ft,is a{Cotswold outlier} The sandy upper slopes give rough grazing,and are home for rabbits,foxes badgers and small mammals.Beech,horse chestnut,hawthorn and pines cap the summit.Kestrels and sparrow hawk may be seen.Redstart nest here.The{Hill {Fort}is still visible in spite of cultivation and landslip.Flint{Stone {Age}objects have been found and{Iron {Age}currency bars(1824).Depressions indicating{pit dwelling}sites remain. In one Iron Age remains were found. Meon Hill with its northerly crest of trees at Jarrett's Brow is a{land mark visible from the Malvern's,Bredon Hill and across Evesham's vale.From its top at ploughing time can be seen{medieval {ridge and furrow}going through the lines of{enclosure hedges}.Today the hill is also used for{motor cycle {scrambling}and{hang gliding.}
